You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions

Paper Title: On The Complexity of Distance-𝑑 Independent Set Reconfiguration

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
Recently, reconfiguration problems have attracted the attention from both theoretical and practical viewpoints.
The input of a reconfiguration problem consists of two feasible solutions of some source problem (e.g., Satisfiability, Independent Set, Vertex Cover, Dominating Set, etc.) and a reconfiguration rule that describes an adjacency relation between solutions.
One of the primary goal is to decide whether one feasible solution can be transformed into the other via a sequence of adjacent feasible solutions where each intermediate member is obtained from its predecessor by applying the given reconfiguration rule exactly once.
Such a sequence, if exists, is called a reconfiguration sequence.
In general, the (huge) set of all feasible solutions is not given, and one can verify in polynomial time (with respect to the input’s size) the feasibility and adjacency of solutions.
Another way of looking at reconfiguration problems involves the so-called reconfiguration graphs—a graph whose vertices/nodes are feasible solutions and their adjacency relation is defined via the given reconfiguration rule.
Naturally, a reconfiguration sequence is nothing but a walk in the corresponding reconfiguration graph.
Readers may recall the classic Rubik’s cube puzzle as an example of a reconfiguration problem, where each configuration of the Rubik’s cube corresponds to a feasible solution, and two configurations (solutions) are adjacent if one can be obtained from the other by rotating a face of the cube by either 909090, 180180180, or 270270270 degrees.
The question is whether one can transform an arbitrary configuration to the one where each face of the cube has only one color.
For an overview of this research area, we refer readers to the surveys    . Reconfiguration problems involving vertex subsets (e.g., clique, independent set, vertex cover, dominating set, etc.) of a graph have been extensively considered in the literature.
In such problems, to make it more convenient for describing reconfiguration rules, one usually view a vertex subset of a graph as a set of tokens placed on its vertices.
Some of the well-known reconfiguration rules in this setting are: Token Sliding (𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}}): a token can only move to one of the unoccupied adjacent vertices; Token Jumping (𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}}): a token can move to any unoccupied vertex; and Token Addition/Removal (𝖳𝖠𝖱​(k)𝖳𝖠𝖱𝑘{\mathsf{TAR}}(k)): a token can either be added to an unoccupied vertex or remove from an occupied one, such that the number of tokens is always (upper/lower) bounded by some given positive integer k𝑘k. Let G𝐺G be a simple, undirected graph.
An independent set of a graph G𝐺G is a set of pairwise non-adjacent vertices.
The Independent Set (MaxIS) problem, which asks if G𝐺G has an independent set of size at least some given positive integer k𝑘k, is one of the fundamental 𝙽𝙿𝙽𝙿{\mathtt{NP}}-complete problems in the computational complexity theory .
Given an integer d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, a distance-d𝑑d independent set (also known as d𝑑d-scattered set
or sometimes d𝑑d-independent set111In fact, the terminology d𝑑d-independent set is sometimes used to indicate a vertex subset such that any two members are of distance at least d+1𝑑1d+1 for d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1.
We note that sometimes a d𝑑d-independent set is defined as a vertex subset S𝑆S such that the maximum degree of the subgraph induced by S𝑆S is at most d𝑑d.
In some other contexts, a d𝑑d-independent set is nothing but an independent set of size d𝑑d.) of G𝐺G is a set of vertices whose pairwise distance is at least d𝑑d.
This “distance-d𝑑d independent set” concept generalizes “independent set”: an independent set is also a distance-222 independent set but may not be a distance-d𝑑d independent set for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3.
Given a fixed integer d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, the Distance-d𝑑d Independent Set (MaxDd𝑑dIS) problem asks if there is a distance-d𝑑d independent set of G𝐺G whose size is at least some given positive integer k𝑘k.
Clearly, MaxD222IS is nothing but MaxIS.
It is known that MaxDd𝑑dIS is 𝙽𝙿𝙽𝙿{\mathtt{NP}}-complete for every fixed d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 on general graphs  and even on regular bipartite graphs when d∈{3,4,5}𝑑345d\in\{3,4,5\} .
Eto et al.  proved that MaxDd𝑑dIS is 𝙽𝙿𝙽𝙿{\mathtt{NP}}-complete for every fixed d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 even for bipartite graphs and for planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree three.
They also proved that on chordal graphs, MaxDd𝑑dIS is in 𝙿𝙿{\mathtt{P}} for any even d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2 and remains 𝙽𝙿𝙽𝙿{\mathtt{NP}}-complete for any odd d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3.
The complexity of MaxDd𝑑dIS on several other graphs has also been studied  7 0.
Additionally, MaxDd𝑑dIS and its variants have been studied extensively from different viewpoints, including exact exponential algorithms , approximability [ref]6  0, and parameterized complexity . In this paper, we take MaxDd𝑑dIS as the source problem and initiate the study of Distance-d𝑑d Independent Set Reconfiguration (Dd𝑑dISR) from the computational complexity viewpoint.
The problem for d=2𝑑2d=2, which is usually known as the Independent Set Reconfiguration (ISR) problem, has been well-studied from both classic and parameterized complexity viewpoints.
ISR under 𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}} was first introduced by Hearn and Demaine .
Ito et al.  introduced and studied the problem under 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}} along with several other reconfiguration problems.
Under 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}}, the problem was first studied by Kamiński et al. .
Very recently, the study of ISR on directed graphs has been initiated by Ito et al. .
Readers are referred to   for a complete overview of recent developments regarding ISR.
We now briefly mention some known results regarding the computational complexity of ISR on different graph classes.
ISR remains 𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴{\mathtt{PSPACE}}-complete under any of 𝖳𝖲,𝖳𝖩,𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TS}},{\mathsf{TJ}},{\mathsf{TAR}} on general graphs , planar graphs of maximum degree three and bounded bandwidth  1 3 and perfect graphs .
Under 𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}}, the problem is 𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴{\mathtt{PSPACE}}-complete even on split graphs .
Interestingly, on bipartite graphs, ISR under 𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}} is 𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴{\mathtt{PSPACE}}-complete while under any of 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}} and 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}} it is 𝙽𝙿𝙽𝙿{\mathtt{NP}}-complete .
On the positive side, ISR under any of 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}} and 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}} is in 𝙿𝙿{\mathtt{P}} on even-hole-free graphs  (which also contains chordal graphs, split graphs, interval graphs, trees, etc.), cographs 6, and claw-free graphs 2.
ISR under 𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}} is in 𝙿𝙿{\mathtt{P}} on cographs , claw-free graphs 2, trees 8, bipartite permutation graphs and bipartite distance-hereditary graphs 9, and interval graphs 4 . Dd𝑑dISR for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3 was first studied by Siebertz 2 from the parameterized complexity viewpoint.
More precisely, in 2, Siebertz proved that Dd𝑑dISR under 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}} is in 𝙵𝙿𝚃𝙵𝙿𝚃{\mathtt{FPT}} for every d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2 on “nowhere dense graphs” (which generalized the previously known result for d=2𝑑2d=2 of Lokshtanov et al. 0) and it is 𝚆​𝚆delimited-[]1\mathtt{W}-hard for some value of d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2 on “somewhere dense graphs” that are closed under taking subgraphs. Since the 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}} and 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}} rules are somewhat equivalent , i.e., any 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}}-sequence between two size-k𝑘k token-sets can be converted into a 𝖳𝖠𝖱𝖳𝖠𝖱{\mathsf{TAR}}-sequence between them whose members are token-sets of size at least k−1𝑘1k-1 and vice versa222They proved the result for ISR, but it is not hard to extend it for Dd𝑑dISR., in this paper, we consider Dd𝑑dISR (d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3) under only 𝖳𝖲𝖳𝖲{\mathsf{TS}} and 𝖳𝖩𝖳𝖩{\mathsf{TJ}}.
